text: Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. text: Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine. Doctor: Yeah, they won't be subtle when they decide to act tough. You're gonna feel it. It's not the occasional, Oh, that kind of hurts. It's the oh man this day hurts every day. Family Member: He has body aches, constantly, his whole body aches and I'm trying to figure out what's causing these body aches. It's like he sat there the other day and was telling me how he was feeling and I know this is terrible, but I started laughing because and I know I was not laughing at you. Yeah, I feel overwhelmed. Like there's nothing I can do. Patient: I’ve been going to a chiropractor for 15 years. Almost on a weekly basis Doctor: Yeah. Patient: To get my back adjusted. They adjust my upper back and my lower back and they adjust my neck. Family Member: But this all over body aching is how long.

text: Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those? Family Member: Yeah. Today he gets- he gets his next Lupron February twelfth. Doctor: Okay. And what about the (Xgeva) Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: That may be helpful. So I’ll, uh, send a note to her. There is a bone-strengthening medication. Family Member: He’s seen a, uh, do you need to see your dentist before you-? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. That kind of stuff. But, uh, but it can be very helpful, especially because the hormone therapy all this time has, can weaken the bones. So, so this may be something that will help, uh, and sometimes it can help with the bone pain, too, uh. You know? So I think all around it’s a good idea to get that started.

text: Patient: Overall, I’m feeling pretty good. Doctor: Did she grill you? Patient: Yes. She did. Doctor: Okay. Well, what are your thoughts on that horrible chemo word? Patient: You know, I’d always like, like to think it was an option of last resort but apparently we’re there. Doctor: It’s not a last resort. It’s an option. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’ve got a, we’ve got to try to kill the cells another way. Patient: Sneak up on it another way. Uh. Doctor: Pretty much. Speaking of which, Dr. C___ says hi.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
